loan.name: Mi

texts.en:
Mrs Mi S. sells food in Chek village in Kandal Province. Her husband, Mr Suong Se, is a farmer who cultivates twice a year. During the rainy season, he cultivates rice, while in the dry season he grows vegetables. In his plantation, he now faces a problem because he does not have enough money to hire a laborer to plow his rice field and buy more rice seeds to cultivate. Thus, his wife, Mrs Mi S., decided to ask for a loan to help. Additionally, she would use part of the loan to purchase fuel for her pump and pesticides to kill all kinds of insects.

Mrs Mi S. is 39 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is attending school while the other is too young to work or study because that child is only the age of four.

loan.use: To hire a laborer, buy more rice seeds, fuel and pesticides.

loan.name: Hean

texts.en: Mrs Hean C. was born in 1959 and she now lives in Kampong Pou village in Kandal Province. She and her husband, Mr Sem Choeurn, are farmers, but they earn only a small income from their plantation. Mrs Hean C. has six children two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the remaining four are attending high school. Despite their business activities, they live in poor conditions in an old house. In order to improve their standard of living, Mrs Hean C. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings in order to buy timbers to build a new house.

loan.use: To buy timbers to build a new house for her household.

loan.name: Suy

texts.en:
This is the second time for Mrs. Suy S. to take out the loan to improve her living conditions. She sells brooms in Kampong Pou Village in Kandal Province. Her husband, Mr. Kour Srey, is a fisherman who can gather small fish because he does not have enough equipment for fishing. Thus, his wife, Mrs. Suy S., decided to ask for a loan to buy a new boat and motor to gather more fish.

Mrs. Suy S. is 39 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is attending school while the youngest one is too young to work or study because that child is four years old. Previously, Mrs. Suy S. had obtained a loan to buy more raw materials to make brooms to sell, and she had fully paid it back.

loan.use: To buy a new boat and motor to gather more fish.

loan.name: Va

texts.en:
This is the second loan of Mrs Va L. to improve her business activities. She is a farmer who cultivates twice a year. During rainy season, she cultivates rice while she grows vegetables in the dry season. Since it is now the rainy season, Mrs Va L. wants to cultivate rice, so she decided to ask for a loan to hire a laborer to work on her farm. She will use the rest of the loan to buy more fertilizers to support her fields to produce a better crop.

Mrs Va L.'s husband, Mr Khut Nget, assists his wife on the plantation. Mrs Va L. is 52 years old and the mother of three children who are all employed in a garment factory.

loan.use: To hire a laborer and to buy more fertilizers.

loan.name: Horm

texts.en:
This is the second time Mrs Horm K. has requested a loan to improve her business activity. She and her husband, Mr Keov Mith, are fishermen in the local lake which is located in Angk village in Kandal Province. In their current business, they have an obstacle because they cannot go to gather fish because of the condition of their boat. Thus, Mrs Horm K. decided to ask for a loan to buy a new boat; she would use the rest of the loan to buy more fish nets for catching fish.

Mrs Horm K. is 47 years old and the mother of five children two of whom are employed in a garment factory while another one helps the parents to gather fish. The remaining two are attending school.

loan.use: To buy a new boat and to buy more fish nets for catching fish.

loan.name: Say

texts.en:
This is the second time Mrs Say S. asks for a loan to improve her living conditions and business activity. She and her husband, Mr Morn Meth, are farmers in Angk village in Kandal Province. In their plantation, they have an obstacle because they do not have enough money to cultivate rice. In order to deal with this, Mrs Say S. is asking for a loan to buy rice seeds to grow rice. She would use the rest of the loan to buy fuel, fertilizers and pesticides.

Mrs Say S. is 35 years old and the mother of six children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while another one is farmer. Two others are attending school while the youngest is too young to work or study because that child is only five.

loan.use: To buy rice seeds, fuel, fertilizers and pesticides.

loan.name: Ear

texts.en:
This is Mrs Ear N.'s second request for a loan to improve her living conditions. She is a cow breeder in Angk village in Kandal Province. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it and so she decided to ask for a loan to buy one more cow for breeding. Her husband, Mr Chhuon Pros, helps his wife to take care of the cows.

Mrs Ear N. is 59 years old and the mother of four children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the remaining two are attending school.

loan.use: To buy one more cow for breeding.

loan.name: Duong Thi

texts.vi: Ch Qu nm nay 42 tui. Gia nh ch c 3 con trong c 1 con ang i hc. Nm 1998 ch tham gia Qu tnh thng v vay vn u t vo xng mc ca gia nh. n nay qua 10 nm vay vn lm n xng mc ca gia nh ch ngy cng c m rng vi rt nhiu loi sn phm nh bn gh, ca g phc v nhu cu s dng ca nhn dn a phng. Vi mc thu nhp 3.000.000/ thng t cng vic sn xut v bn cc sn phm bng g kinh t gia nh ch ngy cng pht trin. Vng vn ti ch mong mun c vay 15.000.000 u t mua g v sn xut cc sn phm bn cho ngi dn a phng.
texts.en:
Ms. Q. is 42 years old. Her family consists of 3 children, 1 of which is in school. In 1998, she joined the organization to invest into her family business of woodwork. After 10 years of borrowing, her family business has grown; producing a variety of furniture, wood doors, and other wood furnishing to meet the demand of the people in her community. Her monthly income is 3.000.000d/month in which she makes from producing and selling wood furnishings. The familys business is growing day to day and so has the income. This next loan, she is requesting 15.000.000d to invest in buying supplies/materials to make furniture, selling them to the people in her community.

Translated from Vietnamese by Lynn Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Buy wood

loan.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Ch Th tham gia vo qu t nm 1997. Vn l nhng ngi dn chm ch, chu kh ngoi thi gian lm nng nghip v chng ch Th cn i T. mua ph liu v bn cho cc i l ti a phng. Qua hn 10 nm vay vn n nay t h gia nh kh khn v kinh t gia nh ch tr thnh h c T. nhp n nh trong thn vi mc T. nhp 3.000.000/ thng.Vng vn ti anh ch mong mun c vay 15.000.000 tip tc u t vn i T. mua ph liu
texts.en:
Ms. T. has been a part of this organization since 1997. She is considered to be a very focused and hard-working individual. Besides working as a farmer with her husband, Ms. T. also buys recycle items to sell to the local businesses in her area. After 10 years of borrowing and struggling financially, her family finances have evolved and since been stable with a monthly income of 3.000.000d/month. This next loan, she is requesting an amount of 15.000.000d as capital in which she plans to purchase more recycle items.

Translated from Vietnamese by Lynn Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Business

loan.name: Loeun

texts.en:
Mr. Loeun C. is a 37-year-old fisherman in Tonlesap Lapke which is our biggest lake and contains the most kinds of fish in Cambodia, and it can provide fish as food to Khmer people over almost the whole country. Loeun earns about 10000 Riel (US$ 2.50) per day. He has four children; one of them lives in the family home and helps with his business. His wife, Mrs. Eam Lun, is a 30-year-old farmer and has been farming for eighteen years. She earns approximately 2000 Riel (US$ 0.50) per day. Loeun lives with his wife and children in Koktlok Kram Commune in Siem Reap Province.

Mr. Loeun would like to request a loan to purchase a fishing boat that would help his fishing activities. He plans to use the rest of the loan to purchase fishing implements such as nets, fishing lines, etc. The loan will improve his investment to support his family better than before.

loan.use: To purchase a fishing boat and fishing implements such as nets, fishing line, etc.

loan.name: Duong Thi

texts.vi: Ch Vng l thnh vin ca Qu tnh thng t nm 1997. T khi tham gia Qu n nay anh ch u vay vn u t vo chn nui v th t m hnh chn nui nh l n nay qua hn 10 nm gia nh ch c h thng chung tri kh quy m vi hn 200 con vt. ln. Ngoi lm chn nui v trng trt, tranh th thi gian nhn ri v chng ch Vng cn i thu mua ph liu v bn li cho cc i l. V th thu nhp ca gia nh ch lun n nh mc 3 n 4 triu ng/ thng. Vng vn ti anh ch mong mun c vay 10.000.000 mua thc n phc v cho vic chn nui vt.
texts.en:
Note: the original description was in English

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Raising

loan.name: Thi Lieu

texts.vi: Ch Liu tham gia vo Qu t nm 2007. Gia nh ch hin c mt con 6 tui. Hin nay ngoi chn nui gia nh ch cn c 1 ca hng tp ho chuyn kinh doanh cc mt hng thc phm, gia dng phc v cho b con a phng. y cng l cng vic em li ngun thu nhp chnh cho gia nh ch. Ngoi ra hng thng gia nh ch cn c thm ngun thu nhp t lng i lm thu ca chng. Vi mc thu nhp bnh qun 3.000.000/ thng kinh t gia nh ch ang ngy cng n nh v pht trin.Vng vn ti ch mong mun c vay 9.000.000 u t vn mua thm cc mt hng phc v b con a phng ngy cng tt hn.
texts.en:
Mrs. Lieu has joined the TYM Fund since 2007. She has a 6-year-old child. Beside raising livestock, she also has a general store selling food stuffs and household appliances to the villagers. This is also the main source of income for her family. There is also an additional income from her husband's job as a hired worker. Her family's financial situation is improving with the average monthly income of 3,000,000VND (about 187USD). This time, she would like to borrow 9,000,000VND (550USD) to purchase more general goods to meet the villagers' demands.

Translated from Vietnamese by Yen Thanh Pham, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Purchase general goods

loan.name: Chanh Thi

texts.vi: Tham gia vo Qu tnh thng t nm 2001 vi s vn vay ban u l 2.000.000 ch Chanh s dng chn nui ln. Vn c nhiu kinh nghim trong chn nui nay c thm vn u t mua thm ln ging v thc n chn nui nn cng vic chn nui ca gia nh ch ngy cng hiu qu. Hin ti gia nh ch u t xy dng chung tri m rng m hnh chn nui thm tru, b. Chng v con trai ch ngoi thi gian i lm th xy cng h tr ch rt nhiu trong vic chn nui. Vi ngun thu nhp n nh 3.000.000/ thng kinh t gia nh ch ngy cng n nh v pht trin hn. Vng vn ti ch mong mun c vay 15.000.000 u t xy nh
texts.en:
Mrs. Chanh joined the TYM fund in 2001, borrowing the first loan of 2,000,000 Vietnamese Dong to raise pigs. As she was experienced with livestock and then had the money to invest, the business soon brought positive returns. Now, her family has plans to expand the farm and start raising buffaloes and oxen. Her husband and her son are both construction workers. They can help her with the farming when they dont have to go to work. The familys income is approximately 3,000,000 Vietnamese Dong per month; the familys financial situation is stable. She plans to make the next loan of 15,000,000 Vietnamese Dong to rebuild her house.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duc Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Repair house

loan.name: Hue Thi

texts.vi: Ch Hu tham gia vo Qu tnh thng t nm 2003. Vi s vn vay ban u 2.000.000 ch s dng u t kinh doanh cc mt hng phc v cho cc em hc sinh ti a phng. Do c v tr kinh doanh thun li, gi c hp l v thi phc v rt nhit tnh ca hng ca ch ngy cng thu ht c nhiu khch hng hn. Hng ngy ch va bn hng va m nhim cng vic chm sc con ci cn anh Ton chng ch i lm th nhm knh. Hin nay cng vic kinh doanh ca gia nh ch ang c rt nhiu thun li v vy ch mong mun c vay thm 15.000.000 u t mua thm mt s mt hng vn phng phm phc v cho cc em hc sinh v cc n v hnh chnh, cc doanh nghip trn a bn x Tam Hng huyn Yn Lc - Tnh Vnh Phc. Thu nhp 4.000.000/ thng
texts.en:
Mrs. Hue joined the TYM fund in 2003. She used the first loan of 2,000,000 Vietnamese Dong to buy and sell office supplies to pupils in Tam Hong County, Yen Lac, Vinh Phuc. Thanks to the stores position, her friendly attitude, and reasonabL. pricing, the store was a success. WhiL. working in the store, she could also take care of her children. Her husband is Mr. Toan, a glazier. Because the store shows potentials, Mrs. Hue plans to borrow 15,000,000 Vietnamese Dong to expand the product lines and introduce new products to customers. The familys income is 4,000,000 Vietnamese Dong per month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duc Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Business

loan.name: Thi Hai

texts.vi: Ch Nguyn Th Hi nm nay 45 tui. Gia nh ch c 5 ngi con trong 2 ngi con trng thnh v c cng vic n nh. Nm 2003 ch Tham gia vo Qu vay vn u t thm vo kinh doanh. Hin nay cng vic em li ngun thu nhp ch yu cho gia nh ch l kinh doanh cc mt hng lm t tre, na. Do c nhiu kinh nghim trong vic nm bt nhu cu tiu dng ca ngi dn i phng nn ca hng ca gia nh ch ngy cng a dng v hng ho v phc v c ngy cng nhiu khch hng. tng thm thu nhp cho gia nh ngoi kinh doanh ch Hi cn kt hp chn nui thm ln, g. Vi mc thu nhp n nh t chn nui v kinh doanh cuc sng ca gia nh ch ngy cng c ci thin, cc con ca ch cng c u t tt hn. Vng vn ti ch mong mun c vay 19.000.000 tip tc u t vo kinh doanh
texts.en:
Mrs. N. Thi Hai, 45 years old, has 5 children. 2 of them are grown-up and have stable jobs. In 2003, Mrs. Hai joined the TYM Fund to expand her inventory for business. Currently, her main source of income is from selling products made from bamboo. With her experiences and ability to foresee the demand of the villagers, she has made and sold more and more products. To increase her family's income, she also raises livestock. As such, her family's standard of living has been improving and her children are better taken care of. This time, she would like to borrow 19,000,000VND (1150USD) to continue investing in her business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Yen Thanh Pham, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Make and sell bamboo products

loan.name: Thu Thi

texts.vi: Ch Thu nm nay 39 tui v tham gia vo Qu tnh thng c gn 4 nm. Gia nh ch vn c ngh lm bnh gia truyn nhng thi gian trc khi tham gia vo Qu s lng bnh gia nh sn xut v bn trn th trng khng nhiu do gia nh thiu vn mua nguyn liu. Nm 2004 ch bn vi chng tham gia vo qu tnh thng vay vn m rng sn xut. C thm vn anh ch u t mua thm go v cc nguyn liu khc phc v cho cng vic lm bnh v th s lng bnh ca gia nh ch cung cp ra th trng ngy cng nhiu. Cng vi vic lm bnh gia nh ch cn kt hp chn nui thm pht trin kinh t gia nh. n nay qua 4 nm tham gia vay vn sn xut, chn nui kinh t gia nh ch Thu ngy cng n nh hn.Nh gia nh ch cng c iu kin u t nhiu hn cho 2 con ang tui n trng. Vng vn ti ch mong mum c vay 15.000.000 u t vo chn nui v mua nguyn liu phc v cho vic lm bnh.
texts.en:
Mrs. Thu is a 39 year old woman. She joined the TYM fund 4 years ago. Her family is a traditional cake maker. Before 2004, the family could not invest enough money to foster the business. She joined the fund and started plans expanding the production. She and her husband had the money to buy supplies, so the quantity of cakes produced much increased. Besides making cakes, they also invested in livestock. For 4 years, the livestock business has been contributing to the familys budget. They now are able to send their children to school. She plans to make the next loan of 15,000,000 Vietnamese Dong to invest more in livestock and buy more cake supplies.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duc Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: livestock and cake supplies

loan.name: Then Thi

texts.vi: Ch Then nm nay 43 tui.Gia nh ch c 4 ngi con trong c 1 ngi con trng thnh. Mc d rt chm ch v c nhiu kinh nghim trong chn nui nhng thi gian trc kinh t gia nh ch vn gp khng t kh khn do thiu vn lm n. Nm 2004 ch xin tham gia vo Qu tnh thng v vay vn u t cho d n chn nui tng thu nhp ca gia nh. C ngun vn vay ca Qu tnh thng v nh s gip thm ca anh em, bn b, gia nh ch quyt nh u t m rng chn nui theo m hnh trang tri. Hin nay cng vic chn nui ln, vt, c ca gia nh ch Then cho thu nhp n nh 4.000.000/ thng. Vng vn ti ch mong mun c vay 15.000.000 mua thm cc loi con ging v thc n chn nui phc v cho vic chn nui ca gia nh.
texts.en:
Mrs. Then is a 43 year old woman. She has 4 children, one of whom has grown up. Though she was a diligent and experienced farmer, before she joined the TYM fund, she did not have money to do businesses. In 2004, she joined the fund, borrowed money, and invested in livestock. Given the money and lots of support from friends, her family managed to convert the old farm into a modern one. Revenue from raising pigs, ducks, and fish brings in 4,000,000 Vietnamese Dong per month. She plans to make the next loan of 15,000,000 Vietnamese Dong to buy more breeding animals and food for them.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duc Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: livestock

loan.name: Nghien Thi

texts.vi: Ch Nguyn Th Nghin nm nay 54 tui. Gia nh ch c 5 ngi con u trng thnh. Nm 2004 ch tham gia vo Qu tnh thng v vay vn u t thm vo chn nui ln sinh sn. Sau mt thi gian, nhn thy cng vic chn nui b cng mang li hiu qu kinh t cao nn gia nh ch u t nui thm b. Hin ti cng vic chnh ca ch l chn nui ti gia nh cn anh nh - chng ch i lm th mc.Vi ngun thu nhp n nh t chn nui ln, b v ngun thu nhp t cng vic th mc ca chng, cuc sng gia nh ch ngy cng c ci thin hn. Vng vn ti gia nh ch mong mun c vay 15.000.000 u t cho vic sa sang cng trnh ph v h thng chung tri to iu kin v c s cho vic chn nui lu di.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nghien Thi N. is a 54 year old woman. She has 5 grown-up children. In 2004, she joined the TYM fund and borrowed money to raise pigs. Latter on, when she realized the financial potential of raising cows, she tried raising them. Now she is mainly working on the farm. Her husband is a carpenter. Income from her business and her husbands job gradually improved their living condition. She plans to make the next loan of 15,000,000 Vietnamese Dong to renovate the farm and repair their house.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duc Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: livestock

loan.name: Thi Mung

texts.vi: Ch Mung tham gia Qu tnh thng nm 2004. Vi s vn vay vng vn u tin l 2.000.000 ch s dng u t vo mua ging v thc n phc v cho chn nui ti trang tri ca gia nh.Vi kinh nghim nhiu nm lm d n chn nui n nay cng vic chn nui ca gia nh ch rt pht trin. Ngoi din tch vn, ao ca gia nh, v chng ch Mung cn mnh dn vay thm vn u t u thu thm 2 mu ao th c. Vn l ngi ph n tho vt vi mong mun cuc sng ca gia nh ngy cng c ca thin nn hng ngy ch Mung v con trai cn i bn tht ln ti cc ch ti thnh ph H Ni. Hng thng cng vic bun bn tht ln cng em li ngun thu nhp ng k cho gia nh ch. Vng vn ti ch mong mun c vay thm 18.000.000 u t vo chn nui pht trin kinh t gia nh
texts.en:
Mrs. Mung joined the TYM Fund in 2004. She borrowed the first loan of 2,000,000VND and used it to purchase animal feed and livestock to raise at home. Thank to her experiences from many years raising livestock, her business is now very developed. Beside utilising the family's garden and pond area, she obtained loans to buy more pond area to raise fish. As an active woman, Mrs. Mung wants to improve her family's standard of living, so everyday she also sells pork in various markets in Ha Noi city with her son. This business is also a significant source of income for her family. This time, she would like to borrow 18,000,000VND (1,100USD) to invest in raising livestock to further improve her family's financial situation.

Translated from Vietnamese by Yen Thanh Pham, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Raising livestock

loan.name: Phan Thi

texts.vi: L mt ph n rt kho tay nn hng ngy ngoi chn nui ch Hot cn lm hng m bn nhm tng thm thu nhp cho gia nh. Tham gia Qu tnh thng t nm 2000, n nay qua 8 nm vay vn chn nui v kinh doanh hin nay kinh t gia nh ch Hot rt pht trin. Chng ch ngoi thi gian i lm cng nhn ti nh my Z151 cng h tr ch rt nhiu trong cng vic chn nui v th ch cng c nhiu thi gian hn u t cho cng vic sn xut v kinh doanh hng m ca mnh. Hin ti anh ch ang sng cng hai ngi con trng thnh. Cc con ch u c cng vic n nh nn hng thng u h tr b m thm v kinh t. Vi ngun thu nhp n nh t chn nui, kinh doanh v lng ca chng cuc sng ca gia nh ch ngy cng tt hn. Ch mong mun c vay thm vn u t m rng m hnh chn nui pht trin kinh t gia nh. Mc vn xin vay 15.000.000
texts.en:
Ms. H. is considered to be very skilled with her hands, so besides raising farm animals she also makes fine paper crafts to help with the familys income. She has been a member of this funding since 2000. After 8 years of investing into her business and raising livestock, her familys income has increased and since been steady. Ms. H. husband also contributes his time caring for the farm animals, in addition to his regular job at the Z151 Company. Her husband help has allowed Ms. H. more time to focus in on her business. They also have two grown children who also live with them. Her children are grown and both of them are able to contribute to the family financially with jobs of their own. Her family is able to live a better life with the resources coming in from her business, agriculture, and her husbands job. She hopes to borrow a loan of 15.000.000d to help remodel and expand her farm.

Translated from Vietnamese by Lynn Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Business

loan.name: Matlubakhon

texts.en:
Matlubakhon A. is 42 years old. She is married with 4 children. Matlubakhon was laid off from her previous job and had to find a stable source of income so she could provide for her family. That is how she ended up as an entrepreneur.

Presently, Matlubakhon sells childrens clothing in the local central market. She offers a large variety of clothing items at a reasonable price. Matlubakhon has been in this trade for 13 years and has gained a rich experience in this kind of activity.

Today Matlubakhon is requesting a loan of 2000 Somoni (600 USD) to purchase some inventory wholesale and increase her turnover capital. She promises to repay the loan within 8 months. Her long-term plan is to open another vending facility. Moreover, Matlubakhon is hoping to use generated profit to help her daughter get a good education in a technical school. We believe her enthusiasm, motivation and desire to improve her living standards will guarantee prompt loan repayment.

loan.use: Purchasing new clothing for children for re-sale

loan.name: Mahfuza

texts.en:
Mahfuza H. is 30 years old. She is the mother of two small children. Due to matters of fate, she ended up living alone and is bringing up her children by herself.

Mahfuza was in need of her own income source to cover her household expenses and some medical expenses for her children. It was then that a friend introduced her to the clothing business. This occurred 5 years ago, and to date she has obtained very good earnings.

Now Mahfuza requires capital to purchase school clothing for teenagers for re-sale being that she has very loyal customers who continue to buy from her ever since she started the business. For this reason, she is requesting a loan for 2000 Somoni (600 USD), which she will repay in 8 months. With your support, Mahfuza will be able to offer her children a higher quality of life.

loan.use: Purchasing new school clothing for teenagers to increase her range of goods

loan.name: Thi Minh's Group

texts.vi: G. Th Minh, sinh nm 1957(Ms 10060010), ngh chnh ca c l nng nghip, chng c hng ngy i lm thu c thu nhp n nh theo thng, cc con c vn cn i hc nn c lun c gng lm vic cuc sng sung tc hn. Thnh thong c cng i ch bun bn rau. Thu nhp bnh qun ca gia nh c khong 3.500.000 vn/ thng. C l nhm trng nhm vay vn gm 5 thnh vin. L: Nguyn Th Mi, sinh nm 1966(Ms 10060001), tham gia vay vn mc: 4.028.000 vn chn nui. o Th Tn, sinh nm 1960 (Ms 10060003), tham gia vn vay mc: 4.028.000 vn u t chn nui ln, g. V Th Mai, sinh nm 1962 (Ms 10060004), tham gia vay vn mc: 4.028.000 vn u t chn nui ln. Nguyn Th T, sinh nm 1963 (Ms 10060005), tham gia mc vn vay: 4.028.000 vn i ch.
texts.en:
Mrs. G. Thi Minh (ID: 10060010), is a farmer. Her husband is a worker with a stable amount of income. As all of her children are in school, Mrs. G. works very hard to improve the familys financial situation. Occasionally, Mrs. G. goes to the market and sells vegetables to make more income. Her familys monthly income is 3.500.000 VND. Other members in her group include: -Mrs. N. Thi Mui (ID: 10060001), borin in 1966, would like to borrow 4.028.000 VND to invest in raising poultries. -Mrs. D. Thi Tan (ID: 10060003), born in 1960, would like to borrow 4.028.000 VND to invest in raising chickens and pigs. -Mrs. V. Thi Mai (ID: 10060004), born in 1962, would like to borrow 4.028.000 VND to invest in raising pigs. -Mrs. N. Thi Tu (ID: 10060005), born in 1963, would like to borrow 4.028.000 VND to do the business in the farmer market.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khoa N., Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: chn nui

loan.name: Phoeurn

texts.en: Phoeurn T., a 53-year-old widow, earns about $4 each day, has four children, and lives in the Kdoldaunteav Commune in the Battambang Province in western Cambodia. Three of her children live at home; her son is a bricklayer, her elder daughter (who is pictured) makes brooms and grows vegetables, and her other daughter works as a hairdresser. Phoeurn also earns a living by making brooms, which she sells throughout her village. She recently realized that she could expand her broom business if she had the capital to purchase more materials and build up an inventory. Therefore, Phoeurn is requesting a loan of $200 to purchase more materials for making brooms.

loan.use: To purchase more materials to make brooms

loan.name: Catherine

texts.en: Catherine is a 38-year-old married mother of 3 children. She lives with her family in Likoni, Mombasa, Kenya. She is the proprietor of a salon, which she started in 1993 out of her small savings. Owing to the increase in the number of clients served, Catherine has applied for US$500 to enable her to renovate her salon to create more space.

loan.use: To renovate her salon to create more space

loan.name: Thi Tham's Group

texts.vi: o Th Thm, sinh nm 1962 (Ms 23070001 ), mc vay: 4.452.000 vn u t bn hng tp ha. C hin ang sng cng chng v hai con. Chng c hng ngy i lm thu, con trai ln i lm c thu nhp khong 1.800.000 vn / thng, con t hin ang hc. C l ngi c uy tn trong lng , nhit tnh trong cng tc x hi v ang gi chc chi hi trng hi ph n ca thn Xun Trch ng thi l cm trng cm vay vn. Thy c li ch ca vay vn pht trin kinh t, c vn ng ch em trong thn tham gia vay vn tr dn. Trong nhm vay ca c gm c: n Th Tuyt, sinh nm 1967 (Ms 23070003 ), mc vay: 4.452.000 vn u t chn nui. Nguyn Th Sng, sinh nm 1957 (Ms 2307 ), mc vay: 4.452.000 vn u t chn nui ln, g. Nguyn Th Thy, sinh nm 1955 (Ms 23070005), mc vay: 4.452.000 vn u t chn nui ln. Nguyn Th Nguyn, sinh nm 1957 (Ms 23070004), mc vay: 4.452.000 u t chn nui ln, g.
texts.en:
Mrs. Dao Thi Tham (ID: 23070001, born in 1962) would like to borrow 4.452.000 VND to open a small shop selling necessities. She is currently living with her husband and her two children. Her husband is a worker while her eldest son has already been working with an income of 1.800.000 VND per month. The younger child is still in school aged. As Mrs. Tham is very popular in her neighborhood because she actively participates in many social activities, she has been elected the head of the group for Xuan Trach town to ask for loans. As the benefits of borrowing loans are visible, Mrs. Tham has persuaded many other women to join the program. Other members in her group include: -Mrs. Don Thi Tuyet (ID: 23070003, born in 1967) would like to borrow 4.452.000 VND to raise poultries. -Mrs. N. Thi Sang (ID: 23070002, born in 1957) would like to borrow 4.452.000 VND to raise chickens and pigs. -Mrs. N. Thi Thuy (ID: 23070005, born in 1955) would like to borrow 4.452.000 VND to raise pigs. -Mrs. N. Thi N. (ID: 23070004, born in 1957) would like to borrow 4.452.000 VND to raise chickens and pigs.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khoa N., Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: bun ban nh

loan.name: Dorothy

texts.en: Dorothy is a 40-year-old entrepreneur and mother of 4 school-aged children. She lives with her husband in Mombasa, Kenya. She began her current business of dressmaking in 1997. She specializes in making both women's and men's clothing. Her business location coupled with her friendly interaction with customers has enabled her to establish a good client base. She owes her success to hard work and perseverance. She has also established a training site for girls who have dropped out of school (currently she has 10), who are trained in dressmaking. She has also employed a full-time tailor to meet her customers' demands. Dorothy plans to move to a more spacious site with her next loan of KSH 42,300.

loan.use: To relocate her business to a more spacious place

loan.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is a 26-year-old single lady who lives in Likoni, Mombasa. She began her salon business 3 years ago. She also sells clothes-making materials, shoes, purses, ties, and other clothing items. The central location of her shop and her many years of doing good business within the community have gained her a good reputation and a wide customer base. Her business has done quite well due to the added advantage of access to loans; she has combined the additional money with hard work and perseverance in order to increase her stock and materials and build a successful income-generating activity. Mary is proud of her accomplishments and the fact that she is now able to contribute toward household expenses. She requires US$500 to further expand her business.

loan.use: To expand her business

loan.name: Khayrullo

texts.en:
Khayrullo A. is 31 years old and married with two children. Khayrullo is a market vendor. For six years he has worked selling clothing for teenagers in the local market. His wife is a housekeeper, thus his business is the only source of income for his family. For this reason, he works hard to bring sustenance back to his home. Khayrullo wants his children to get a good education to have a better chance to succeed in the future. This is what makes his sacrifice worthwhile.

In order to grow his business, Khayrullo is requesting a loan of 2000 Somoni ($600). He will use the loan to purchase merchandise in order to offer a wider selection to his customers and increase his income. With the rotation of supplies in his business, he plans to repay the loan within ten months. The well-being of Khayrullos family and his business are in your hands. Khayrullo and his family are sincerely grateful for your support.

loan.use: To purchase more stock of clothing for teenagers.

loan.name: Supiya

texts.en:
A widow and mother of two children, Supiya opened her business selling clothing for women seven years ago to support her family. She fought to provide for her family and educate her children, who are working adults today thanks to her example. Sacrificial and hardworking, she supported not only her two children but her elderly parents as well.

Supiya has invested countless hours and efforts to develop her business and establish a strong client base. Now her adult son (who is pictured in the photo) is helping his mother with her business. With the beginning of a new season, Supiya wants to add new seasonal stock to her goods. She is requesting a loan of 3000 Somoni ($900) that she promises to repay over ten months. With this loan, she will be able to make a good profit by having the right inventory in stock to meet demand as the season changes.

Supiya and her friendly family would like to express their gratitude for everyone supporting her.

loan.use: To purchase of new women's clothing to increase her range of goods.

loan.name: Matlyuba

texts.en:
Matlyuba R. is 44 years old. She is married and the loving mother 4 children. She worked for 2 years in a gift shop, and thanks to the savings of her husband, 9 years ago she was able to start her own business. She now sells clothing for children. She gets help from her children, who take care of the store in the afternoon.

Thanks to her hard work, her customers increased and she had to rent the store next door to expand and offer a better variety. She is now requesting a loan of 4100 Somoni (1200 USD) which she will use to buy school uniforms for children due to the season. She commits to repay the loan over a period of 10 months. Matlyuba is thankful for your generosity and help.

loan.use: Purchasing school uniforms for children to increase her range of goods

loan.name: Mavludakhon

texts.en:
Mavludakhon Y. is 32 years old. She is married with 2 adorable children. Mavludakhon has been able to combine her love of children with a successful business selling teenagers clothing at a busy market in Tursunzade, Tajikistan. Her business is one of the best in town with good quality products and several locations.
Mavludakhon currently has one stall at the market. Eventually, Mavludakhon would like to open a store in a permanent facility. Mavludakhon has requested a loan of 2000 Somoni (600 USD) to help purchase new inventory of autumn clothing for teenagers. She promises to repay the loan within 8 months. She will be able to help many teenagers keep warm and dry through the rainy autumn months and hopes to make a good profit by having the right inventory in stock to meet demand as the season changes.

loan.use: Purchasing new clothing for teenagers for re-sale

loan.name: Mr Den Net's Group

texts.en:
This group, which is located in Slab Ta Aon village in Kandal Province, consists of four people and they will use the loan for different purposes.

Mr Den N. is the group leader and he is a pig breeder who raises 10 pigs. His wife, Mrs Sam Ran, sells fruit in the local market. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it so her husband, Mr Den N., decided to ask for a loan to buy more fruit for his wife's business.

Mr Den N. is 42 years old and the father of four children, one of whom is staying at home to cook food and do housework, while the others are attending high school.

loan.use: To buy more fruit for his wife's business.

loan.name: Kidawa's Tumaini Group

texts.en:
Kidawa is 26 years old. She is married with 4 children aged between 6 and 2 years old. She has been a fish and bites (chapati) seller since 2007. Every day, she works from 6am to 5pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $155 from her sales.

Kidawa now hopes for a loan to expand her business by adding to her current stock. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing with tailoring, clothes sales, chips and bites sales.

loan.use: To expand her business by adding her current stock

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 26, 2008)

loan.name: Mrs Chhuon Chantha's Group

texts.en:
Four people in Preak Thom village in Kandal Province make up this group and Mrs Chhuon C. is the group leader. She is a security guard in a company. Her husband, Mr Or Ti, is a wedding chef in the local village. Since their workplace is too far from home and they typically spend a lot of money on their transportation, Mrs Chhuon C. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to buy a motorbike for going to work. She hopes to reduce her family's expenses with this loan.

Mrs Chhuon C. is 38 years old and the mother of five children, one of whom is a tailor while the others are attending school.

Mrs Chhuon C. will share this loan with the other members of her group.

loan.use: To buy a motorbike for going to work.

loan.name: Zuwena's Subira Ina Mpaka Group

texts.en:
Zuwena is 25 years old. She is married with 3 children between the ages of 7 months and 7 years old. She has been a clothes and perfumes seller since February 2008. She works everyday and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 from her sales.

Zuwena now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes and perfumes for re-sale. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Khadija, who has a business selling bites (snacks) and home utensils.

loan.use: To buy more clothes and perfumes for re-sale.

loan.name: Mrs Chan Sophal's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This Village Bank which consists of eight people is located in Dei Edth Kaoh Phos village in Kandal Province and they plan to use the loan for different purposes.

The group leader, Mrs Chan S., owns a small restaurant where she sells food. Since her business is going well, Mrs Chan S. decided to ask for a loan to buy more ingredients in order to cook delicious food for her customers.

Mrs Chan S. is a 51-year-old widow with four children one of whom works abroad while the remaining three are enrolled in the local schoO..

loan.use: To buy more ingredients in order to cook the delicious food for her customers.

loan.name: Mwajuma

texts.en:
Mwajuma is 30 years old. She is married with 4 children between the ages of 3 and 12 years old. She has been a charcoal and firewood seller since 1998. Everyday she works from 8am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $80 from her sales.

In the past, Mwajuma has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania (Kiva's Field Partner) to expand her business. Mwajuma now requests a loan to buy more charcoal and firewood for her business.

loan.use: To buy more charcoal and firewood for her business.

loan.name: Pili

texts.en:
Pili is 49 years old. She is a widow with 4 children. She is a fish and firewood seller. Everyday she works from 6am to 8pm at her business.

In the past, Pili has took out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania (Kiva's Field Partner) to expand her business. Pili now requests a loan to buy more fish and firewood for her business.

loan.use: To buy more fish and firewood for her business.

loan.name: Talat

texts.en: M. Talat is a very responsible and hard working woman. She is married and has 4 adorable children. Several years ago Maria decided to start her own business. She was working in a garment factory near her home and knew a lot about making clothing, so with some savings she opened a small seamstress shop in her house. In time, she gained customers and a good reputation for her work. Talats children are all studying at school and the next year two of her sons are planning to enter university and need tuition. That is the reason that she needs to continue growing her business. She asks for a loan of 740 USD that will be invested in buying fabrics to increase her production and cover her customers' demands. She commits to return the original amount in 12 months. Help this family improve their quality of life by contributing to the growth of Talats business. They sincerely thank you for your help.

loan.use: To purchase fabrics for sewing dresses.

loan.name: Mr Vet Vy's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
In Chouy Dang village in Kandal Province, 23 people have formed a village bank and Mr Vet Vy is the village bank president, selected by the group members. He is a construction worker and cow breeder. As well as these businesses, he is a poultry breeder who raises 10 chickens in his house. Since his cow and chicken businesses are going well and they are growing bigger and bigger, Mr Vet Vy does not have enough money to purchase grass for his cows and chicken food for his chickens. Thus, he decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. His wife, Mrs Yin Sok, is a housewife who cooks very deliciously for her household. Mr Vet Vy is 48 years old and the father of four children who are all attending school.

My Vet Vy will share this loan with the other members of the village bank. One member has an end-of-term loan and the rest have monthly payment loans. The end-of-term loan member is not required to pay aN. principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments maN. months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loan.use: To buy grass for his cows and chicken food for his chickens.

loan.name: Khadija's M'hanuni Group

texts.en:
Khadija is 47 years old. She is married with 3 children aged 17, 14 and 7 years old. She has been a food seller since 2007. Every day, she works from 9am to 4pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $125 from her sales.

In the past, Khadija has taken out one successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. Khadija is now looking for a loan to buy more food items like rice, maize flour, vegetables, and bananas for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Hawa, who has a business dealing with charcoal and bites sales.

loan.use: To buy more food items for the expansion of her business

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 26, 2008)

loan.name: Atsufe

texts.fr: Atsufe A. est propritaire dune boutique dalimentation gnrale depuis bientt 3 ans Kpalim, une ville situe environ 120 kilomtres de Lom, la capitale togolaise. Elle est ge de 35 ans, marie et mre de 2 enfants. Elle dsire par ce crdit augmenter la capacit de son commerce en achetant des cartons de laits, de sucres, des sacs de riz et autres produits afin de rpondre au besoin de la clientle. Atsufe compte sur cette opportunit pour subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants.
texts.en:
For almost three years, Atsufe A. has been the proprietor of a general store in Kpalim, a town situated about 120 km from Lom, the capital of Togo. She is 35, married and the mother of two children. She would like to use this loan to expand her business by buying cases of milk, sugar, sacks of rice and other products so as to meet the needs of her clientele. Atsufe is counting on this opportunity to be able to better support her children.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: purchase cases of milk, sugar, sacks of rice and other products for re-sale

loan.name: Dany

texts.en:
Mr. Dany D., 28, and his wife, Mrs. Saren Chorn, 26, live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 2000 and have one son.

Mr. Dany has been a silk weaver since he was married, using a skill he learned from his wife. In addition to weaving, Dany also raises cows, pigs, and goats at home. Mrs. Saren has been a silk weaver since she was sixteen years old, using a skill she learned from her aunt. The couple sells their finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Dany is requesting a loan of $200 to purchase silk materials for weaving.

loan.use: To purchase silk materials for weaving.

loan.name: Mafunda's Farijika Group

texts.en:
Mafunda is 34 years old. She is married with 4 children aged between 17 and 3 years old. She has been a food (chapati & soup) seller since 2003. Every day, she works from 7am to 10pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $125 from her sales.

Mafunda is now requesting a loan to expand her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Fatma, who has a business dealing with coconut sales.

loan.use: To expand her business

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 26, 2008)

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: To purchase piglets, build a pigpen, and buy supplies to grow rice.

loan.name: Naret

texts.en:
Mrs. Naret C., 36, and her husband, Mr. Moeun Sok, 39, who live in a small village about seventeen kilometers south of Phnom Penh, were married in 1994 and have three children: two sons and one daughter. Two of their children study in local schools and the youngest one still stays at home.

Mrs. Naret has been a tailor for over two years. She operates her business at home. Her husband has been a driver for a company for four years. Naret is requesting a loan of US$ 500 to purchase another sewing machine and repair some parts of her house.

loan.use: To purchase another sewing machine and repair some parts of her house

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 25, 2008)

loan.name: Mrs Sok Vanna's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The Village Bank which is located in Kaoh Kaev Leu village in Kandal Province consists of twenty-three people who plan to use the loan for a variety of purposes. For instance, Mrs S. V., who is the village bank president, is requesting a loan to buy zinc to fix her house's roof because it is now the rainy season. Mrs S. V. and her husband, Mr Pal Chhorn, are farmers in the local village. Mrs S. V. is 53 years old and the mother of four children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the remaining three are enrolled in the local school.

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Fourteen members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. The members who have end-of-term loans are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term.

End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loan.use: To buy zinc to fix her house's roof.

loan.name: Aliou

texts.fr: Aliou I. est g de 45 ans, mari et pre de 5 enfants. Il est boucher depuis 9 ans au centre commercial de Kpalim, une ville situe environ 120 kilomtres de Lom, la capitale togolaise. I. dsire avec ce crdit acheter des bufs et des boucs et des bliers pour labatage afin de rpondre aux besoins de sa clientle. Les gains issus de sont activit lui, permettront damliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Aliou I., 45, is married and the father of 5 children. He has been a butcher for 9 years in the commercial center of Kpalim, a town situated about 120 km from Lom, the capital of Togo. I. wants to use this loan to buy some cows and goats and rams for slaughter to satisfy the needs of his customers. The profits he makes from this business will allow him to improve living conditions for his family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: to buy cows and goats and rams for slaughter

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FECECAV - Oct 26, 2008)

loan.name: Nou

texts.en:
Mrs. Nou H., 37, is a widow with two sons, and lives in a small village off of National Road Two about twenty kilometers south of Phnom Penh. One of her sons is a garment factory worker and other one is a construction worker.
Mrs. Nou has been a garment factory worker for ten years. She works in a garment factory in Phnom Penh City. Nou and her son travel to work by motor taxi and the costs are a bit high, so she needs to buy a motorbike to cut down on costs. Therefore, she is requesting a loan to purchase a motorbike to drive to work.

loan.use: To purchase a motorbike to drive to work.

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 26, 2008)

loan.name: Abduvahob

texts.en: V. Abduvahob is 35 years old. He is married with 3 children. Abduvahob has a small restaurant where he serves breakfast, lunch and dinner. Prior to opening his own business, he worked at a restaurant where he learned the ins and outs of the trade. When he first started his business he opened to serve only breakfast because he worked at night. Once his place became more popular he was able to dedicate his whole time to the business. Abduvahob woud like a loan to invest in tables, chairs and utensils. He is asking for 1000 USD for the term of 12 months. With this money, Abduvahob will be able to expand his business, earn more profit and in turn help his children complete their school studies and continue studying at the university. Contribute to the growth of his business and they will be grateful.

loan.use: To purchase tables, chairs and utensils for expanding his restaurant business.

loan.name: Koffi

texts.fr: Koffi Zoumkp est g de 26 ans, clibataire sans enfants. Il est revendeur de CD audio et vido, depuis bientt 2 ans, Kpalim, une ville situe environ 120 kilomtres de Lom, la capitale togolaise. Koffi souhaite avec ce crdit de FECECVA, alimenter sa boutique afin de rpondre aux exigences des clients de plus en plus croissantes. Koffi compte sur cette opportunit pour gagner plus de fonds afin de venir en aide son petit frre qui est sur les bancs de lcole.
texts.en:
Koffi Zoumkp is 26 years old, single, and has no children. For almost two years now, he has been a retailer of CD's and DVD's in Kpalim, a city located about 120 km from Lom, the Togolese capital. Koffi would like to use this FECECVA loan to supply his shop in order to meet customer demands that continue to grow and grow. Koffi intends to use this chance to earn more funds, so that he can come to the aid of his younger brother, who is in school.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To buy boxes of CD and DVD

loan.name: Zahira's Tusaidiane Group

texts.en:
Zahira is 24 years old. She is married with 1 child, 2 years old. She has owned and run her own shop and restaurant since 2003. Everyday she works from 6am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $250 from her sales.

Zahira is now looking for a loan to expand her business by increasing her current stock. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Asha, who also has a business selling bites (snacks).

loan.use: To expand her business by increasing her current stock.

loan.name: Awali

texts.fr: Awali A. est un mcanicien 2 roues, Kpalim, une ville situe environ 120 kilomtres de Lom la capitale togolaise. Ag de 32 ans, Awali est mari et pre de 2 enfants. Par ce crdit, il souhaite acheter des outils de travail satisfaire pleinement sa clientle, et aussi amnager son atelier. Monsieur Awali espre amliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille par cette opportunit.
texts.en:
Awali A. is a bike mechanic in Kpalim, a city located about 120 km from Lom, the Togolese capital. Awali is 32 years old, married, and the father of two children. With this loan, he would like to buy work tools to fully meet the expectations of his customers and also to fix up his shop. Mr. Awali hopes to improve the living conditions for his family by this opportunity.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To buy work tools and also to fix up his shop

loan.name: Phum

texts.en:
Mr Phum L. was born in 1959 and he now lives in Sdao Kanlaeng village in Kandal Province. He is a farmer who cultivates twice a year. In plantation, he now faces a small problem because he does not have enough money to hire a laborer with oxen to plow the rice field. In addition, he would like to purchase more rice seeds and fertilizers for cultivating. His wife, Mrs Dong Vy, owns a small grocery store in the local village.

Mr Phum L. has seven children, four of whom are employed in a garment factory while another is a construction worker. The others are attending school. His wife is on the right of the picture.

loan.use: To hire a laborer with oxen to plow the rice field and to purchase rice seeds and fertilizers.

loan.name: Sokha

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokha B., 54, and her husband, Mr. Un Choen, 56, live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1975 and have six children: one son and five daughters. Three of their children are married and live outside the family home, and the other three children weave silk at home. Mr. Un is a farmer.

Mrs. Sokha has been a silk weaver since she was married, using a skill he learned from her neighbor. She sells the family's finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Sokha is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase silk materials for her daughter to weave.

loan.use: To purchase silk materials for weaving.

loan.name: Mwanahawa's Nuru Njema Group

texts.en:
Mwanahawa is 30 years old. She is married with 2 children, ages 4 and 12. She has been a charcoal seller since March 2008. Everyday she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $25 from her sales.

Mwanahawa now requests a loan to buy more charcoal for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Rauhiya, who has a business selling coconuts and firewood.

loan.use: To buy more charcoal for her business.

loan.name: Chamroeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Chamroeun C., 38, and her husband, Mr. Vuthy Nhem, 38, live in a small village off of National Road Two about twenty kilometers south of Phnom Penh. They were married in 1994 and have four children: two sons and two daughters. Two of their children study in the local school and other two are still young and stay at home.
Mrs. Chamroeun and her husband have been selling sugarcane juice and Khmer cakes for over one year. They buy them from Ta Khmao market for resale in the village. Chamroeun is requesting a loan of US$150 to purchase soft drinks for resale at her shop.

loan.use: To purchase soft drinks for resale.

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 26, 2008)

loan.name: Soam

texts.en:
Soam P., 53, lives in Siem Reap with her husband, Kinh Nen, and their two children. She sells grocery products out of her home and makes US$5 per day, while her husband works in construction and typically makes US$3 per day. One of their children works near Banteay Srey temple which is located in the Angkor Wat temple complex. She owns a small souvenir stand and sells to all the tourists who pass through the area. Soam P. would like to help her daughter's souvenir business and believes that through expansion, the family's economic situation can be improved.

She has asked for a loan of US$1000 to purchase another stand for her daughter's business and would like to expand her own grocery store inventory with the any remaining money. She believes that her family has two very good businesses running and would like to see both increase their customer base and expand to help support the family.

loan.use: Purchase another stand for souvenir sales

loan.name: Nget

texts.en: Mrs Nget S. N. is a villager in Ank Duong village in Kandal Province. She is 20 years old and the mother of a child who is too young to work or study because that child is only one. She is a farmer and her husband, Mr Hoeurn Huor, is a fisherman and pig breeder. Although Mrs Nget S. N. and her husband both have businesses, they still live in an old house which needs to be repaired. Thus, Mrs Nget S. N. decided to ask for a loan to fix her house in order to live in better conditions.

loan.use: To fix her house in order to live in better conditions.

loan.name: Tabu's Wapendanao Group

texts.en:
Tabu is 23 years old. She is married with 2 children, 3 and 5 years old. She has been a tailor and bites (snacks) seller since March 2008. Everyday she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $80 from her sales.

Tabu now requests a loan to expand her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Raya, who also has a business selling clothes.

loan.use: To expand her business.

loan.name: Shara

texts.en:
Shara is 37 years old and married with five children between the ages of 20 years and 7 months old. She has sold firewood since 2007. Everyday, she works from 8 am to 8 pm at her business, and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 from her sales.

Shara is requesting a loan to buy more firewood for her business.

loan.use: To buy more firewood to sell.

loan.name: Morm

texts.en:
Mrs Morm C. was born in 1968 and she now lives in Sdao Kanlaeng village in Kandal Province. She grows vegetables in the field which is next to her house. In her plantation, she now faces a small problem because she does not have enough money to buy vegetable seeds, so she decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. She will use the rest of the money to purchase fertilizers and pesticides in order to produce a better crop.

Her husband, Mr Chhum Chhoeun, is a construction worker who can earn a small income to support his family. Mrs Morm C. has two children who attend the local school. Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loan.use: To buy vegetable seeds and purchase fertilizers and pesticides.

loan.name: Yao

texts.fr: Yao A. est g de 35 ans, mari et pre de 3 enfants. Il est un redoutable cordonnier Kpalim, une ville situe environ 120 kilomtres de Lom, la capitale togolaise. Il souhaite par ce crdit de FECECAV, acheter des outils de travail notamment des peaux de btes, des colles, des fils et aussi amnager son atelier afin de rpondre aux exigences de la clientle
texts.en:
Yao A., 35, is married and the father of 3 children. He is an excellent shoemaker in Kpalim, a town located about 120 km from Lom, the capital of Togo. He wants to use this loan he is requesting from FECECAV to buy tools of his trade, especially leather, glue, and thread, but also to renovate his workshop so as to better satisfy his customers.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: purchasing the tools of his trade and renovating his workshop

loan.name: Sarim

texts.en:
Mr. Sarim S., 28, and his wife, Mrs. Sarem Khim, 28, live in a small village across the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 2000 and have three children: one son and two daughters. In addition to their children, the couple also has one sister who is a silk weaver and their elderly mother living with them.

Mr. Sarim has been selling cows for eight years. His wife has been raising pigs for three years. Besides selling cows and raising pigs, the couple also farms. Sarim is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase pigs to raise; to buy seed, fertilizer, and pesticide for growing rice; and also to buy silk materials for his sister's weaving.

loan.use: To purchase pigs to raise, buy supplies for growing rice, and buy silk materials for weaving.

loan.name: Guessin

texts.fr: Guessin R. est ge de 48 ans, marie et mre de 4 enfants. Elle est revendeuse de tchoukoutou , une boisson locale qui consomme par la plupart de la population, Kpalim, une ville situe environ 120 kilomtres de Lom, la capitale togolaise. Elle exerce cette activit depuis plus de 7 ans et demeure sa principale source de revenu. Avec ce crdit, madame Guessin souhaite acheter des sacs de mas et de mil pour la prparation de tchoukoutou. Ceci permettra de gagner plus dargent afin de subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Guessin R. is 48 years old, married, and the mother of four. She is a retailer of "tchoukoutou", a local drink that most people consume in Kpalim, a city located about 120 km from Lom, the Togolese capital. She has been in this work for over seven years, and it remains her main source of income. With this loan, Ms. Guessin wishes to buy sacks of corn and millet for making tchoukoutou. This will enable her to earn more money in order to provide for the needs of her children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To buy sacks of corn and millet

loan.name: Mama

texts.fr: Mama D. est une dynamique couturire Kpalim, une ville situe environ 120 kilomtre de Lom, a capitale togolaise. Elle est ge de 35 ans, marie et mre de 3 enfants. Mama souhaite par ce crdit acheter une machine coudre et des tissus pour les revendre aux clients. Ce faisant elle dgagera des profits lui permettant de subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Mama D. is a dynamic seamstress in Kpalim, a town situated about 120 km from Lom, the capital of Togo. She is 35, married, and the mother of 3 children. Mama wants to use this loan to buy a sewing machine and some cloth to re-sell to her customers. In this way, she will make income from her business that she can use to support her children.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: purchase a sewing machine and cloth

loan.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: L mt ngi ph n sng vng nng thn lu nm nn c K. c rt nhiu kinh nghim trong chn nui. Tham gia Qu tnh thng t nm 2000 vi s vn vay ban u l 700.000 c K. s dng u t mua ln v nui. Tn dng ngun thc n sn c ca gia nh v nhng kinh nghim tch lu c trc nn d n em li cho gia nh ngun thu nhp n nh. T d n chn nui nh n nay qua 8 nm vay vn v s dng vn hiu qu, c ch tch lu c s vn ng k u t xy dng khu chn nui kh quy m. c thm vn u t mua thm ln v nui vng vn ti gia nh c K. mong mun c vay 18.000.000 Thu nhp 4.000.000/ thng
texts.en:
As a young women living in the rural area for quite some time, Ms. K. has a lot of experiencing raising farm animals. She has been a part of this organization since the year 2000 with an initial loan of 700.000d. Ms. K. had used the money she received to buy hogs to raise. With her past experience in raising farm animals, she is able to conserve and prepared the right amount of food sources to each animals; therefore, stabilizing her familys income. From a small ranch and 8 years later from borrowing capital, she has seen a success. She and her husband are able to save up, expanding and upgrading their ranch. Ms. K. is hoping to borrow 18.000.000d to buy more hogs. Her monthly income is 4.000.000d/month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Lynn Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Raising

loan.name: Preab

texts.en:
Preab R., 44, lives in Siem Reap with her husband, Tuy Soin, and their five children. The children range in age from 8-22 and the older two work in construction. Preab R. grows lettuce and various other vegetables to sell in the local food market. She typically makes US$2 per day from her business and her husband is a farmer who makes US$2.50 per day out in the fields. Their monthly expenses are around US$70 for food and US$25 for utilities, so the family is seeking ways to increase their income.

Preab R. has requested a loan of US$350 from CREDIT to purchase more fertilizer for her crops. She took over her vegetable business from her parents and would like to continue expanding in the future.

loan.use: Purchase fertilizer

loan.name: Koffi

texts.fr: Koffi M. est g de 45 ans, mari et pre de 4 enfants. Il tient une boutique dalimentation gnrale Kpalim, une ville situe environ 120 kilomtres de Lom, la capitale togolaise. Il dsire augmenter la capacit de son commerce en achetant des cartons de laits, de sucres, des sacs de riz et autres botes de conserves. Ses ventes lui permettront de rembourser le crdit et de dgager des profits pour la survie de sa famille
texts.en:
Koffi M., 45, is married and the father of 4 children. He tends a little general store in Kpalim, a town that is located about 120 km from Lom, the capital of Togo. He wants to bolster his business by buying cases of milk, sugar, sacks of rice, and tinned goods. His sales will allow him to reimburse the loan and have profit to support his family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: buying cases of milk, sugar, sacks of rice, and tinned goods

loan.name: Thi Loan's Group

texts.vi:
ch C. th Loan Ms 09040026 nm nay 40 tui, l mt gio vin, thi gian bn rn nhng ch rt chm ch. Ngoi gi L.n lp, v nh ch lun ginh thi gian chm sc gia nh,v chng ch sinh c 3 con, c 3 chu u ang i hc.B m chng, l cn b nh nc ngh hu, v vy m gip ch rt nhiu cc cng vic trong gia nh v nui dy con ci.Hng ngy ngoi cng vic c quan v 2 v chng ch thng thu mua trng ca cc h gia nh trong xm, cc a bn ln cn, bn cho cc cng ty.Nn thu nhp t 200.000 VND n 250.000 VND / ngy. V vy ch v cc thnh vin trong nhm hon tr vn rt tt, C. k II ny ch ng k vay 4.704.000 VND b sung vn mua trng. Cc thnh vin trong nhm ch :

  • ch nguyn th Chin Ms 09040034 vay mc 3.808.000 VND mua cm ln
  • ch L th Bc Ms 09040031 vay mc 4.256.000 VND i ch tht b
  • ch Ng th Do Ms 09040029 vay mc 3.186.000 VND mua cm g ( tr trong 25 tun )
  • ch Nguyn th Thm Ms 09040032 vay mc 3.186.000 VND mua cm g ( tr trong 25 tun )
texts.en:
Mrs. C. Thi Loan (ID: 09040026), aged 40, is a very hard-working teacher. Besides the time at school, she devotes all her time to her family. She has 3 children, all of whom are still in school. Her parents-in-law are retirees, who help her a lot with all the work at home. Everyday, after finishing work, she and her husband often buy eggs from people in her neighborhood and adjacent areas and sell them to companies. This helps them earn about 200.000 VND-250.000 VND per day. She and other members in her group have finished paying back loans of the previous rounds. In the next round of loan, Mrs. Loan would like to borrow 4.704.000 VND to buy more eggs. Other members in her group include: -Mrs. Nguyen Thi Chien (ID: 09040034) would like to borrow 3.808.000 VND to buy food for the pigs. -Mrs. Le Thi Bac (ID: 09040031) would like to borrow 4.256.000 VND to buy pork to sell in farmer market. -Mrs. Ngo Thi Do (ID: 09040029) would like to borrow 3.186.000 VND to buy food for the chickens (she will pay it back in 25 weeks) -Mrs. Nguyen Thi Thom (ID: 09040032) would like to borrow 3.186.000 VND to buy food for the chickens (she will pay it back in 25 weeks)

Translated from Vietnamese by Khoa Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: vn bun bn

loan.name: Norma Rosibel

texts.es: Norma Rosibel D. M. vive en Lourdes, municipio del departamento D. La Libertad. DesD. hace ya un par D. aos, Norma maneja un pequeo puesto, donD. venD. alimentos bsicos y D. consumo diario. Junto a su esposo trabajan ambos para cubrir sus gastos y mantener a sus dos hijos, que an son menores D. edad, y requieren atencin y cuidado constante, por lo que Norma Rosibel debe diariamente hallar tiempo y fuerzas para potenciar su negocio y criar a sus nios. Mediante esfuerzo y con la ayuda D. algunos prestamos, la familia M. ha logrado salir adelante, pero el reciente incremento D. gastos familiares por el alza D. precios en el mercado, y los mltiples gastos D. educacin infantil, ha llevado a Norma a aumentar sus horas D. trabajo, e incluso a vender sus productos a plazo y entregarlos con promesa D. pago, pues es D. absoluta relevancia que maximice sus oportunidades D. ingreso. Con la mirada puesta en el desarrollo laboral que d cabida a una mejor educacin y futuro D. sus hijos, Norma solicita un prstamo a Integral para comprar ms mercadera para su tienda, (consoms, arroz, frijol etc.), y as crecer como empresaria y madre a la vez.
texts.en:
Norma Rosibel of M. lives in Lourdes, municipality of the department of La Libertad. It has been several years since Norma sells food for daily consumption at a small food store. Norma and her husband work to cover the expenses of the home and to maintain their two children, who are still under age, and require attention and constant care. Norma is a woman is lots of energy, as she has to find time to keep up with the business and raise her children. The M. family has managed to do well, but the recent increment of family expenses due to the rise of prices in the market, and the multiple child related expenses such as education, have forced Norma to work longer hours, and to sell her products on credit basis with a promise of payment. It is of absolute importance that the M. maximize their income opportunities. In order to proviD. her children with a better education and future, Norma is requesting a loan to buy more merchandise for the store, (rice, beans etc), and thus to grow her business and proviD. for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Antonella Sacconi, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To purchase more merchandise for her store, (rice, beans etc)

location.town: Lourdes Coln, departamento de La Libertad

loan.name: Thi Thanh's Group

texts.vi:
Ch Nguyn th Thanh Ms 09020033 nm nay 57 tui, ch ang sng cng b m chng, chng, 2 con. nui dy cc con n hc 2 v chng ch rt vt v : lm rung, nui ln, b, g, i ch thu mua ph liu.... Chnh v vy m ch rt thch hnh thc vay, tr ca Bnh Minh cdc nn ch ng k tham gia v hon tr rt tt. Chu k II ny ch li tip tc ng k vay mc 3.808.000 VND mua g ging, hng ngy ch i ch st vn v chng ch chn nui nn thu nhp bnh qun t 120.000 VND n 150.000 VND/ ngy. Cc thnh vin khc trong nhm :

  • ch D. th Bnh Ms 09020028 vay mc 3.808.000 VND i ch tht
  • ch Trn th Lan Ms 09020037 vay mc 2.242.000 VND mua cm ln v i ch ( Tr trong 25 tun )
    • ch Nguyn th To Ms 09020038 vay mc 1.534.000 VND thm vn mua cm ln ( Tr trong 25 tun )
  • ch Nguyn th Tnh Ms 09020032 vay mc 3.808.000 VND kinh doanh vt liu xy dng
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi Thanh (ID: 09020033), aged 57, is currently living with her parents-in-law and her two children. To support her two children who are still in school, she and her husband have to do a wide range of work- from farming, breeding pigs, cows, and chickens to collecting wastes. Mrs. Thanh is very interested in the loan method, so she joined the program. And she has been very on time in paying back the loans. In the next round of loan, Mrs. Thanh would like to borrow 3.808.000 VND to buy chickens and breed them. Collecting wastes and raising poultries help her family earn about 120.000 VND-150.000 VND per day. Other members in her group include: -Mrs. Duong Thi Binh (ID: 09020028) would like to borrow 3.808.000 VND to buy meat and sell it in the farmer market. -Mrs. T. Thi Lan (ID: 09020037) would like to borrow 2.242.000 VND to buy food for the pigs and go to the farmer market (paying back in 25 weeks) -Mrs. Nguyen Thi Tao (ID: 09020038) would like to borrow 1.534.000 VND to buy food for the pigs (paying back in 25 weeks) -Mrs. Nguyen Thi Tinh (ID: 09020032) would like to borrow 3.808.000 VND to buy and sell construction materials.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khoa Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: vn chn nui

loan.name: Sarom

texts.en: Sarom H. is 68 years old and sells Khmer noodles by moving through residential areas, earning about $1.80 each day. She is married to Phum Phan, a bricklayer who moves from construction site to construction site and earns about $2.40 each day. Together they have six children, only one of whom is married. The other four children contribute to the family's income by working as restaurant waiters, souvenir salespersons, and peddlers of used goods. To increase her family's income, Sarom is requesting a loan of $800, which would be used to strengthen her noodle business and more importantly purchase a motorcycle, which would help her son (who is also pictured) transport used goods for sale around their community.

loan.use: To purchase a motorcycle for transporting retail goods.

loan.name: Chum

texts.en: Chum E., 56, is married and lives with four children in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. Since 1990, she has earned a living as a tailor and is able to make US$3 each day. Her income is aided by her children who work as garment factory workers. Her husband, Un Chet, 59, is a motor-taxi driver and is able to earn US$4 per day. Mrs. E. is requesting a loan from Kiva via CREDIT, Kiva's local partner, to purchase an additional sewing machine for her children. The rest of the loan will be used to purchase a motorbike for her son to start a moto-taxi business.

loan.use: To purchase a sewing machine and a motorbike.

loan.name: Pendo

texts.en:
Mambo from Mwanza Tanzania!

Pendo M. is a married woman with two children, aged eleven and twelve. She is thirty-five years old. She started her ice-cream business in 2005. She works six days a week for four hours a day and is assisted by two employees. She earns a monthly profit of about $100 from this business. Pendo is requesting a loan of $450 to purchase another refrigerator and additional containers. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so she can use it while in process of paying back her loan a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers ownership of the equipment to the client. The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that is allows clients.

loan.use: To purchase a refrigerator and additional containers.

loan.name: Touch

texts.en: Touch S., 42, has a business selling rice with roast sausage in front of her home and is able to make US$10 in revenue each day. Her husband is a musician, that plays guitar in a restaurant. This couple has five children, two of whom are students, two others are employed and one stays at home to help her mother with her business. Mrs. Touch is requesting a loan from Kiva, via Kiva's Credit local partner, of US$1000 to expand her business. She would like to increase the amount of rice and sausage she sells and wants to offer more meats such as roast beef and pork and to offer beers and wine. She told a loan officer that she will work hard for her children to complete their bachelor degree. (She is pictured with the black shirt)

loan.use: To increase the amount of rice and sausage sold

loan.name: Semeni

texts.en:
Mambo from Mwanza Tanzania!

Semeni M. is a married woman with four children between the ages of eleven and twenty-two years old. She is forty-five years old and started her firewood business in 2006. She works seven days a week for eight hours a day, and her husband assists her in running the business. She earns a monthly profit of about $110. She is requesting a loan of $350 to purchase additional stock of firewood. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity and range of stock that she sells. Semeni thanks you for your support.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so she can use it while in process of paying back her loan, a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers ownership of the equipment to the client. The advantage of micro leasing over traditional microfinance loans is that is allows clients.

loan.use: To purchase additional stock of firewood.

loan.name: Krouch

texts.en: Krouch L., 61, has a business selling vegetables in the market and is able to make around US$5 of profit per day. Selling vegetables has been a difficult business, as there is high inflation and weather conditions that have not been conducive to a good growing season. Her husband operates a motor-taxi business and he typicallymakes US$5 of profit per day as well. This couple have five children and all of them are employed with a different types of work. Krouch told a loan officer that even though all of the family members are employed they still face some problems such as high inflation. She also adds that her husband's business faces problems with competition and soaring gas prices. Many customers have no will to pay more even they know input prices have skyrocketed. To eliminate some cost that she spends everyday, she requests a loan to purchase a motorbike to transport the vegetables to the market. (She took picture with her husband)

loan.use: To purchase a motorbike to transport the vegetables to the market.

loan.name: Mao

texts.en:
Mao C., 42, is a widowed grocery vendor and resides with her elderly mother and her younger brother in Prey Veng, Cambodia. She typically makes around US$5 of profit each day and is aided by two daughters who work as garment factory workers in Phnom Penh.

Selling groceries has been a difficult business, as there are many competitors and high inflation which makes prices skyrocket. She is asking a loan from Kiva via Credit, the local partner, to add her grocerys inventory. This will satisfy her and allow her to attract many buyers as well. In the future, she wants to open a tailor shop for her daughters. She does not want her children to work away from their home town.

loan.use: To add her grocerys inventory.

loan.name: Louk

texts.en:
Louk R., 35, is a farmer living in Siem Reap with her husband, Pi Pit, and their four children. Their children are aged 13, 11, 3, and they also have a young 3 month old baby. Louk R. typically makes US$2 working her fields each day and her husband makes US$5 per day as a construction foreman. The family's monthly expenses are US$75 for food, US$30 for utilities, and US$25 for public transportation and costs of motortaxis. Louk R. has asked CREDIT for a loan of US$1000 to purchase fertilizer for her crops to improve her crop yields. In the future, Louk R., would like to purchase another plot of land to grow more crops and diversify her options for customers.

Louk R. was unavailable for a photograph at the time of the interview, so her husband is pictured above.

loan.use: Purchase fertilizer

loan.name: Chea

texts.en:
Chea P. is 53 and has a business selling fish at the market. She is able to earn approximately $3 each day. This business is good as fish is a favorite food among Cambodian people, who prefer fish to meat. But she still faces some problems. She does not have enough capital to sell a large amount of fish each day. Her husband Nov Mee is 54. He is a motor-taxi driver and makes $4 per day. The high price of gas has put many motor-taxi drivers off of the road and the remaining are making less profit. This couple has four children together, two of who are employed as garment workers and one of whom is married and no longer at home.

Mrs. Chea is asking for a loan from Kiva via local partner Credit to purchase a motorbike for family transportation. This will reduce some of the cost that this family spends on motor-taxi.

Mr. Nov is pictured because his wife is not available.

loan.use: To purchase a motorbike for family transportation.

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 25, 2008)

loan.name: Soam

texts.en: Soam S., 41, sells fish and groceries in her village. She earn approximately US$7 per day. Her husband, Chhuon Vantha, 45, works as a construction worker building houses and normally makes US$5 a day. This couple has six children, two of whom are employed as garment workers with a salary US$150 each a month.
